It is legal for a woman to abort a fetus in the first trimester, and further along if there are complications. No repercussions, no trials for murder, just kill the baby, it isn't viable yet...
 But on the other hand, a pregnant woman is attacked in her first trimester and her baby dies. Her attacker is charged with murder of an unborn child, or intentional/unintentional conduct against a pregnancy. 
 A pregnant woman is attacked and murdered. Now her attacker faces double homicide.
 My question is why is it ok for a woman to kill her baby and it is perfectly legal, but if someone else does it, why are they charged with murder, or manslaughter?

emoticon_xangel I study fallacies and am not presenting an opinion on the matter but here is a very interesting exapmle presented by Mary Anne Warren, in her analysis of a familiar anti-abortion argument: 
 1) It is wrong to kill innocent human beings 
 2) Fetuses are innocent human beings 
 Therefore, it is wrong to kill fetuses. 
 Warren argues that, in fact, this argument faces its own dilemma: either it is guilty of equivocation - or it is guilty of question-begging. 
 It is easy enough to argue that "innocent human beings" means two different things in the premises - and thus the argument equivocates. For example: 
 innocent human being in premise 1 = "conscious of moral choice, but not guilty of committing/choosing an immoral act" 
 innocent human being in premise 2 = "innocent because the fetus is not capable of moral intentions and choices in the first place" 
 IF two different senses of "innocent human being" are thus at work in the argument - then the argument equivocates: while we might agree that it is wrong to kill innocent human beings in the first sense - this is not immediately relevant to fetuses as innocent human beings in the second sense, and so the conclusion does not follow. 
 [Alternatively, if we are not equivocating - if we somehow mean "innocent human beings" in the exact same sense in both premises - then the argument begs the question. That is, the premises taken together would then mean: 
 it is wrong to kill innocent human beings, where "innocent human beings" includes fetuses. 
 BUT: this is precisely the conclusion we're seeking to establish (or, the question under discussion). Our argument in this version then amounts to 
 [P] it is wrong to kill innocent human beings, where "innocent human beings" includes fetuses 
 [C] therefore it is wrong to kill fetuses [as innocent human beings] 
 The argument thus goes in a circle, as the premises already include everything we're attempting to assert in the conclusion - alternatively, the premises offer no additional argument, evidence, or information in support of the conclusion. Rather, the premises merely restate the conclusion, and the conclusion merely restates the premises. Or: the question, "Is it wrong to kill fetuses?" is begged as the answer to the question is merely assumed in the premises.
Why are fetuses "innocent" human beings? Do they instantly cease to be "innocent" human beings as soon as they pass through the vagina of a woman?

1) It is wrong to kill innocent human beings
 2) Fetuses are innocent human beings 

 
 It has an unstated premise, 3) Abortion is killing, which is the most contentious of all and where pro-choice argumentation, should, IMO be concentrated.
 
 In contrast I do not believe the objections already raised hold, they're the same things you could say about any deductive logic.
 
 ie 1) Bill Clinton is a man
 2) All men are mortal
 
 Therefore Bill Clinton is mortal
 
 That is, the premises taken together would then mean:
 All men are mortal, where "all men" includes Bill Clinton.
 BUT: this is precisely the conclusion we're seeking to establish (or, the question under discussion). Our argument in this version then amounts to
 [P] All men are mortal, where "all men" includes Bill Clinton
 [C] therefore Bill Clinton is mortal [as a man] 
 
 The argument thus goes in a circle, as the premises already include everything we're attempting to assert in the conclusion - alternatively, the premises offer no additional argument, evidence, or information in support of the conclusion. Rather, the premises merely restate the conclusion, and the conclusion merely restates the premises. Or: the question, "Is it wrong to kill fetuses?" is begged as the answer to the question is merely assumed in the premises.
 
 You can see the fact the conclusions include no more information than the premises is not an objection to a deductive argument, in fact it is a requirement of the validity of a deductive argument.

1) It is wrong to kill innocent human beings 
 2) Fetuses are innocent human beings 
 Therefore, it is wrong to kill fetuses. 
 
Nobody can argue that fetuses purposely do any harm. However, to be guilty or innocent requires, as an absolute minimum, that the entity in question has a mind, in other words, a mental existence. A rock or a house cannot be innocent or guilty, neither can several cells moments after conception, which will eventually become a person but not for many months yet. My contention has always been that a fetus doesn't become a person until it has a rudimentary mind - which is on or after roughly the 30th week of pregnancy. After that, one can refer to it as an "innocent human being".
